#T_SP=webanno.custom.Ecosystem|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Focalpoint|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Locationofstudy|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Mainhypothesisandcorrespondingresults|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Method|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Reccomendationsandsuggestions|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Researchquestions|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Timeperiodofstudy|
#Text=Using a trait  _based dark diversity approach to evaluate natural recovery potential in forests\r�lise Deschenes,�Kierann R.

#Text=Santala,�Jonathan Lavigne,�Isabelle Aubin\rFirst published: 13 August 2024\r�\rhttps://doi.org/10.1111/rec.14251\rAuthor contributions: IA, KRS, ED conceived and designed the research; KRS, ED compiled the data; ED analyzed the data; ED, KRS, JL, IA wrote and edited the manuscript.
#Text=Coordinating Editor: Elise Gornish\rSECTIONS\rPDF\rTOOLS\rSHARE.
#Text=Abstract\rUtilizing ecosystems' natural recovery potential is crucial for enhancing the scale and efficacy of restoration efforts.
#Text=However, this potential is currently underutilized in restoration ecology, and barriers to natural species recruitment remain poorly understood.

#Text=In this study, we develop an analytical framework that combines trait  _based and dark diversity approaches to evaluate understory plant community recovery in smelter  _impacted forests and identify factors limiting recovery for absent species.
#Text=A community completeness index (CCI) was calculated in 18 naturally recovering smelter  _impacted forests and three reference forests in Sudbury, Ontario, Canada.
#Text=The CCI was used to identify sites that deviate the most from their target communities and was compared to traditionally used indicators of plant recovery.

#Text=Community weighted means (CWM) of traits for observed and dark diversity species were compared, and principal components analysis was used to identify relationships between traits of observed and missing species among study sites.
#Text=Species unable to recover passively (i.e. with high dark diversity probabilities) were generally tall and/or large seeded.
#Text=Understory plant community recovery was structured along two functional gradients, plant economics and size, which both coincided with distance to the smelter.
#Text=Dark diversity and trait analyses were useful for identifying barriers to natural recovery and, therefore, providing guidance on targeted restoration actions.

#Text=We conclude by discussing the limitations and opportunities of the dark diversity approach in a restoration context, highlighting the importance of carefully defining habitat  _specific species pools and critically assessing the ecological significance of dark diversity probabilities.

#Text=Implications for Practice\r* Our study examines how combining dark diversity and trait  _based approaches can guide restoration efforts following natural recovery.\r* Community completeness indices quantify how complete a plant community is and can be used to prioritize areas for restoration.\r* Dark diversity probabilities can be used to identify the trait values of absent species that may indicate barriers to recovery.\r* In areas of our study system where recovery is more advanced, species with high dark diversity probabilities can be targeted for reintroductions.
#Text=In more impacted areas, enhancing soil conditions is required before reintroductions can take place.
#Text=Introduction.

#Text=Approximately 75% of the world's land has been altered as a result of anthropogenic activity, including resource development, unsustainable harvest, pollution, fragmentation, and exotic species invasions (IPBES�2019).
#Text=To mitigate the impact of these disturbances, the UN has committed to restoring at least 1 billion hectares over the next decade (UNEP�2021).
#Text=To achieve this goal requires large investments in restoration projects as well as greater capacity to deliver proven, scalable solutions (Menz et al�2013).

#Text=The effectiveness of some restoration actions remains limited, and in some cases, natural recovery, defined as the spontaneous and unassisted recovery of a degraded ecosystem (Chazdon et al�2024), has been shown to achieve comparable or even better outcomes compared to   active� restoration (Crouzeilles et al�2016; Atkinson & Bonser�2020; Prach et al�2020).

#Text=Restoration programs using natural or   passive� recovery potential have also been shown to generally be more cost  _effective and applicable over larger areas (Chazdon & Guariguata�2016; Chazdon et al�2024).

#Text=At present, the potential for natural recovery to achieve desirable outcomes is underutilized in restoration ecology, notably due to uncertainties regarding its effectiveness and predictability (Chazdon�2014; Arroyo  _Rodr�guez et al�2017).

#Text=Initial colonization following disturbance generally consists of non  _target pioneer and ruderal species able to disperse to and grow in disturbed areas (Prach et al�2001; del Moral et al�2007).

#Text=Even under favorable conditions, numerous later successional species may struggle to establish due to dispersal and establishment limitations or biotic interactions (del Moral et al�2007; Hemrov� & M�nzbergov��2015).
#Text=In some cases, reestablishment of pre  _disturbance communities may be impossible if the disturbance has drastically changed the growing conditions.
#Text=In these cases, hybrid or novel mixtures may be more appropriate target systems, especially in the face of global change (Hobbs et al�2009).

#Text=Assisting natural recovery with targeted restoration approaches, such as enrichment plantings, could be used to overcome specific obstacles to reach a desirable community, while utilizing nature's intrinsic recovery potential (Crouzeilles et al�2020; Shono et al�2020).

#Text=Forest plant community recovery is typically evaluated by comparing plant diversity, abundance, and structure with those of a reference ecosystem to understand how plant assemblages recover over time (Wortley et al�2013; Gatica  _Saavedra et al�2017).

#Text=However, suitable reference ecosystems may be difficult to find due to a long history of disturbance or a lack of information on the state of the ecosystem before degradation (Durbecq et al�2020).

#Text=Further, while measures based on abundant species have been widely used to evaluate forest recovery, recent studies recommend identifying absent yet suitable species, known as dark diversity (Moeslund et al�2017; Noreika et al�2020; Sluis�2020).

#Text=Dark diversity is defined as the suite of species that are absent from a site, but present in the habitat  _specific species pool, that is, observed in the surrounding region and theoretically able to inhabit the site  _specific ecological conditions (P�rtel et al�2011).

#Text=At the site level, a dark diversity approach can be used to calculate a community completeness index (CCI) that quantifies the proportion of the species pool observed at a site, providing a measure of the distance of a disturbed ecosystem from its potential in terms of diversity (P�rtel et al�2013).
#Text=CCI can thus be used to assess the success of restoration efforts over time and inform management decisions (P�rtel et al�2013; Lewis et al�2017).

#Text=For instance, low CCI values may signify sites lacking many suitable species, indicating a need for active restoration efforts, while high CCI values suggest successful recovery, as a greater proportion of the species pool is observed at the site.
#Text=Further, expressing CCI on a relative scale facilitates comparisons among communities independently of species pool size (P�rtel et al�2011; P�rtel et al�2013).
#Text=Dark diversity can also be calculated at the species level and used to identify species that are frequently absent yet suitable within the region.

#Text=Identifying these species sheds insight on the mechanisms controlling plant recruitment and persistence during recovery, such as dispersal, germination, emergence, establishment, plant interactions, community, and metapopulation dynamics (P�rtel et al�2011; Lewis et al�2017; Moeslund et al�2017).
#Text=This provides crucial information for prioritizing conservation actions, including targeting reintroduction efforts for frequently absent species (Noreika et al�2020).

#Text=Increasingly, plant trait  _based approaches are being integrated into forest restoration practices as a promising way to improve our understanding of the mechanisms controlling community assembly processes within recovering ecosystems (Laughlin�2014; Carlucci et al�2020; Aubin et al�2024).

#Text=Traits are used to understand how plants respond to environmental changes (response traits; Violle et al�2007) or to assess the recovery of ecosystem functions following environmental change (effect traits; Violle et al�2007; Kraft et al�2015; Carlucci et al�2020).

#Text=By combining dark diversity and trait  _based approaches, we can better identify functional syndromes of co  _occurring trait attributes (McIntyre et al�1999) that are less likely to recover naturally, the ecological filters impeding their recovery, as well as potential mitigation actions to overcome these barriers via active restoration.

#Text=While a dark diversity approach has been used to evaluate the success of active restoration (Moeslund et al�2017; Noreika et al�2020; Sluis�2020), to our knowledge, no studies have used this approach to assess the potential of natural recovery to achieve desirable outcomes.

#Text=In this study, we develop an analytical framework that utilizes both trait  _based and dark diversity approaches to evaluate spontaneous understory plant community recovery following disturbance.
#Text=We demonstrate the application of this approach to sites left to naturally recover in the smelter  _impacted forests of Sudbury, Ontario, Canada.

#Text=This is an area internationally recognized for environmental damage associated with acidification and metal contamination from ore smelting starting in the 1880s, with subsequent recovery of canopy cover following major reductions in smelter emissions beginning in the 1970s (Watson et al�2012).

#Text=We apply this framework to (1) evaluate the CCI as a measure of natural recovery in smelter  _impacted forests, (2) identify species or functional syndromes that are slow to recover passively, and (3) examine environmental filters that may be impeding recovery.
#Text=We conclude by identifying some potential restoration interventions to mitigate factors impeding recovery, and discuss opportunities and limitations of this framework.
#Text=Methods.
#Text=Study Area.
#Text=The study is located in the city of Greater Sudbury, Ontario, Canada (46 degrees 30 N, 81 degrees 00 W), within the Great Lakes  _St.
#Text=Lawrence Forest Region (Rowe�1972).
#Text=This region is characterized by glaciofluvial deposits of sand and gravel and thin, discontinuous glacial till (Rousel & Jansons�2002).
#Text=Soils are podzolic, with soil layers that are typically thin (less than 10 cm) due to erosion, overlying bedrock (Gillespie et al�1983).
#Text=Average temperatures in January and July are  13.5 and 19 degrees C, respectively.
#Text=The total annual precipitation is 899 mm, with almost half falling as rain during the growing season from May to September (Environment Canada�2018).

#Text=Historic industrial activities and their related environmental consequences (e.g. drought, low nutrient availability, and frost heave) have led to extensive loss of canopy and ground cover, soil erosion, increased soil acidity, and high metal concentrations in soils and plant tissues (Courtin�1994; Wren et al�2012).
#Text=Three main smelter complexes have been operational during the twentieth century: Coniston, Falconbridge, and Copper Cliff.
#Text=Copper Cliff is the largest and is still operational, as is the smaller Falconbridge complex.
#Text=Coniston was closed in the 1970s, following the expansion of the Copper Cliff Complex and the construction of the SuperStack in 1972.
#Text=By the 1970s, it was estimated that the 17,4,000 ha surrounding smelters were nearly completely barren of vegetation.
#Text=An additional 64,000 ha extending outwards were considered semi  _barren of vegetation (Amiro & Courtin�1981; Winterhalder�1995).
#Text=The degree of ecosystem degradation has been linked to smelter proximity, with the greatest emissions and most impoverished vegetation observed closer to smelters (Freedman & Hutchinson�1980).
#Text=Following the closure of the Coniston complex and the construction of the Superstack, emissions declined greatly, and the semi  _barren communities began to recover (Watson et al�2012).

#Text=These efforts have allowed for the partial recovery of forests dominated by�Betula papyrifera�Marshall,�Pinus resinosa�Aiton,�P. banksiana�Lamb.,�Populus tremuloides�Michx.,�P. grandidentata�Michx., and�Quercus rubra�L.
#Text=(Sinclair�1996).

#Text=Despite this recovery, plant communities, especially within the upland barren zones, continue to be affected by elevated levels of soil metals (mainly Ni, Cu, and Co), low soil pH, nutrient availability, and soil organic matter (Wren et al�2012).
#Text=Local Dataset: Sudbury Ecological Risk Assessment.
#Text=We used vegetation and environmental data from the Sudbury Ecological Risk Assessment (SERA), a subproject of the Sudbury Soils Study (SARA Group�2009).
#Text=The Sudbury Soils Study was conducted from 2001 to 2008 and encompassed 40,000 km2.

#Text=The purpose of the SERA was twofold: to evaluate the risks to terrestrial plants, animals, and humans from exposure to metals originating from air emissions from local smelters; and to provide information to support the recovery of local ecosystems in areas known to have been affected by historic mining and smelting (SARA Group�2009).

#Text=The SERA dataset contains 21 sites, 18 naturally recovering sites with low soil pH and elevated Cu and Ni concentrations, and three reference sites chosen to represent areas that had not been impacted by emissions from the smelters, with metal concentrations in soils that were representative of natural local background levels (SARA Group�2009).
#Text=Reference sites were selected to have otherwise similar conditions to recovering sites and could therefore be used for comparison purposes (see SARA Group�2009�for more details).
#Text=Each reference site represented a stand type historically frequent in the region: one�Abies balsamea�(L.)
#Text=Miller stand, one�P. resinosa�stand, and one mixed stand of�Acer rubrum�L.,�B. papyrifera,�Pinus strobus�L., and�Picea mariana�(Miller) Britton, Sterns & Poggenburgh.
#Text=The dataset contains one additional site that we excluded from our analysis because it had been limed and seeded in the early 1980s.
#Text=Vegetation Data.
#Text=The SERA dataset contains both understory and overstory vascular plant community data.
#Text=For this study, we evaluated the natural recruitment and recovery of vascular understory species, which have been slow to recover within the Sudbury region (Santala et al�2016).
#Text=The 21 sites were used to create the local matrix of observed species relative percent cover, for all vascular plant species less than 1 m in height, including seedlings of woody species.
#Text=Relative percent cover was obtained by dividing each species' cover by the total cover within the site.
#Text=Total canopy cover and maximum tree height from overstory data were calculated to characterize environmental conditions.
#Text=Species nomenclature follows Brouillet et al (2022), apart from three genera that were pooled at the genus level (Amelanchier�sp.,�Carexsp., and�Salix�sp.).
#Text=Environmental Data.
#Text=Within the SERA study, soil cores were collected from each site to evaluate their physical and chemical characteristics.

#Text=Measures of organic matter (total C and total N), soil exchange complex chemistry (cation exchange capacity (CEC), base saturation, Ca, Mg, and Ca:Mg ratio), and fertility (N as ammonium and extractable P, K, Fe, Mn, Mg, and Fe:Mn ratio) were obtained from composite core samples of the 0�5 cm layer (SARA Group�2009).
#Text=To evaluate the risk from airborne particulate emissions of chemicals of concern, Ni, Cu, Co, As, Pb, Se, and Cd concentrations were measured.
#Text=To assess substrate, the cover of coarse woody debris, lichen, litter, liverwort, moss, rock, grass, clubmoss, herbs, and bare ground were evaluated.
#Text=Values of selected environment variables at each site are available in Table�S1.
#Text=See SARA Group (2009) for more details.
#Text=Plant Community Recovery Metrics.
#Text=We calculated understory species richness and total canopy cover within each site, as these are frequently used metrics of community recovery (Gatica  _Saavedra et al�2017).
#Text=We also used a plant community recovery metric utilized by the SERA practitioners, the risk assessment rank (SARA Group�2009).

#Text=This ranking was developed using a weight  _of  _evidence approach involving four lines of evidence: soil characterization, toxicity testing, a plant community survey, and a decomposition assessment.

#Text=Each line was evaluated separately, and then the quality and quantity of the data from each line were integrated to produce a final site rank that indicates the level of site impact observed relative to reference sites: none to low, moderate, or high (SARA Group�2009).

#Text=Regional Dataset: Ontario Ecological Data Repository\rTo estimate the habitat  _specific species pool for the 21 study sites from the SERA, we used historical forest inventory data from the Ontario Forest Ecosystem Classification, a component of the Ecological Data Repository (EDR) of the Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry (Government of Ontario, Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry�2019).
#Text=To limit the data to forests similar to the three reference sites, we selected data for sites within a 100 km radius of Sudbury.
#Text=We excluded forests with an overstory composition different from the three reference sites, which were dry upland forests.
#Text=This site selection was validated by confirming that these were realistic target forests for the area with restoration practitioners from the Sudbury area.

#Text=In total, 119 sites fulfilled these criteria and were used to create the regional matrix of species relative percent cover for all vascular plant species less than 2 m in height, including seedlings of woody species.
#Text=Relative percent cover was obtained by dividing each species' cover by the total cover within the site.

#Text=Species names were verified to ensure compatibility between both the SERA and EDR datasets, with nomenclature following Brouillet et al (2022), except for three genera pooled at the genus level (Amelanchier�sp.,�Carex�sp., and�Salix�sp.).
#Text=Species from a genus occurring in less than five sites and at less than 1% cover were removed from the EDR dataset.
#Text=Trait Dataset.

#Text=We selected traits related to species' potential to colonize and survive in disturbed sites to identify traits of observed species and species with high dark diversity probabilities (see Table�S2�for definitions, range of values, units, and description of each trait's relationship to dark diversity and disturbance).

#Text=Seed mass, seed production, seed dispersal, and lateral spread were selected as they relate to dispersal and colonization ability (Westoby et al�2002; Klime ov� & Klime �2007; Vittoz & Engler�2007).

#Text=We selected maximum height, growth rate, and specific leaf area (SLA) as they are associated with competitive vigor and the ability to colonize quickly following disturbance (Westoby�1998; Westoby et al�2002).

#Text=Trait data were obtained from the Traits of Plants in Canada (TOPIC; Aubin et al�2020) and TRY Plant Trait Databases (Kattge et al�2020), among other sources (datasets and sources are referenced in Supplement�S1).

#Text=Plant maximum height, seed weight, and SLA were collated as numerical values, while growth rate, seed production, and lateral extension were classified into ordinal groups (see Table�S3) and converted to numerical values for comparability.
#Text=There were two missing trait values (seed weight for�Dirca palustris�and SLA for�Diphasiastrum digitatum) that we populated with the median value of all species for each trait.
#Text=Analysis.
#Text=Estimations of Dark Diversity and Community Completeness.

#Text=Figure�1�shows a diagram of the analytical framework used to answer the three questions of our study: (1) how have sites recovered, (2) which species are absent, and (3) why are they absent  First, we calculated the habitat  _specific species pool and dark diversity probabilities for each of the 21 sites using probabilistic methods developed by Carmona and P�rtel (2020).

#Text=This method assigns probabilistic estimates of dark diversity based on the deviation of the observed co  _occurrence patterns of each pair of species from a null expectation of random co  _occurrences.

#Text=The standardized difference between observed and expected joint occurrences describes if a pair of species co  _occurs more frequently than expected randomly and can then be used as the indicator value for the species pair.

#Text=The probability that an absent species belongs to the dark diversity of a site is high if its co  _occurrences with observed species in that site are predominantly positive, whereas the opposite is true if its co  _occurrences with the observed species are predominantly negative (Carmona & P�rtel�2020).
#Text=We estimated the co  _occurrence probabilities between species pairs using the regional dataset described previously.

#Text=These co  _occurrence probabilities were used to estimate the habitat  _specific species pool and dark diversity probabilities of the 21 study sites, producing a matrix of site   species dark diversity probabilities.

#Text=This matrix was transformed into a relative dark diversity probability matrix by converting the raw dark diversity values into proportions relative to the total dark diversity observed at each site, totaling 100%.

#Text=The relative dark diversity probability matrix resembles a relative abundance matrix as it exhibits a high proportion of zeros and a positively skewed distribution, where the majority of species have low dark diversity probabilities, and few have higher probabilities.

#Text=For each site, we calculated the total dark diversity as the sum of the dark diversity probabilities of all species absent from the site (Carmona & P�rtel�2020) and the CCI as the ratio of species richness to total dark diversity, shown as percentages (ratio   100/[1 + ratio]).
#Text=This equation expresses community completeness as the percentage of species richness in the habitat  _specific species pool.
#Text=Figure 1\rDatasets and their role in analytical steps to address three study questions.

#Text=We based our analyses on three matrices: (A)�R�matrix (sites   environmental variables), (B)�L�matrix (sites   species) with regional (L�regional) or local (L�local) relative percent cover data, and (C)�Q�matrix (traits   species).

#Text=We used these matrices to calculate the dark diversity probability matrix (dark diversity probability [DDP] of sites   species), observed community weighted means (CWM) (sites   traits for observed species), and dark diversity CWM (sites   traits for absent species).
#Text=Arrows indicate input (arrows pointing in) or output (arrows pointing out) matrices for each analytical step.
#Text=CCI, community completeness index; Obs, observed; PCA, principal components analysis.

#Text=Statistical Analysis\rTo evaluate how CCI compares to traditional measures of recovery success, we evaluated how CCI varied with the SERA ranks as determined by practitioner's using a non  _parametric Kruskal�Wallis test.
#Text=We also evaluated Pearson's correlations between CCI and richness, canopy cover, as well as distance to smelter.
#Text=To characterize observed and dark diversity communities, we calculated community weighted means (CWM) of the traits of observed and dark diversity species within each site.
#Text=CWMs are calculated by multiplying the relative cover of each species by its corresponding trait value and summing these values across all species in the community (Lavorel et al�2008).
#Text=CWM thus provides a weighted average of the trait value for the community (Lavorel et al�2008).

#Text=For observed species, CWM values were weighted by the relative cover of observed species in the site, whereas for absent species, CWM values were weighted by the relative dark diversity probabilities of absent species in the site.

#Text=We used a non  _parametric Kruskal�Wallis test to evaluate whether CWM differed between observed species and dark diversity species, as variances were not homogeneous between both groups (observed and dark).

#Text=To visualize relationships between environmental variables and identify relationships between traits among study sites, we conducted principal components analyses (PCA) on (1) the standardized environmental variables, and (2) the standardized CWM of traits of observed and dark diversity species.
#Text=Finally, we extracted the 10% of species with the highest sum of dark diversity probabilities and visualized their standardized trait values within a third PCA.
#Text=Statistical analyses were performed using R 4.2.2 (R Core Team�2022).
#Text=Co  _occurrence patterns and dark diversity were calculated using the   DarkDiv� package (Carmona & P�rtel�2020).
#Text=Kruskal�Wallis tests were performed using the   stats� package (R Core Team�2022).
#Text=CWMs of traits were calculated using the   FD� package (Lalibert� et al�2014).
#Text=PCA were performed using the   vegan� package (Oksanen et al�2022).
#Text=Results.
#Text=The CCI did not vary with the Ecological Risk Assessment rankings used by the practitioners in Sudbury, although highly impacted sites showed large within  _group variability (Fig �2A).
#Text=Reference sites had a mean CCI of 21.9% (SD 3.55%), a mean richness of 18.7 species (SD 2.1 species), and a mean cumulative canopy cover of 217% (SD 27%).
#Text=Moderately impacted sites had mean CCI of 17.6% (SD 4.73%), a mean richness of 12.9 species (SD 4.5 species), and a mean cumulative canopy cover of 116% (SD 44%).
#Text=Highly impacted sites had a mean CCI of 14.6% (SD 7.12%), a mean richness of 10.9 species (SD 5.8 species), and a mean cumulative canopy cover of 44% (SD 23%).
#Text=CCI was correlated with richness (Fig �2B), but not with canopy cover or distance to smelter (Fig �2C�&�2D).

#Text=Figure 2\rCommunity completeness index (CCI) as a function of commonly used site  _level metrics of plant community recovery: (A) Sudbury Ecological Risk Assessment ranking, (B) richness, (C) canopy cover, and (D) distance to smelter in 18 naturally recovering smelter  _impacted forests and three reference forests in Sudbury, Ontario, Canada.
#Text=Sample size per risk assessment rank and Kruskal�Wallis�p�value are indicated in (A), Pearson's correlations are presented in (B)�(D).
#Text=Species with higher dark diversity probabilities showed larger maximum height and seed weight values (Fig �3).

#Text=Figure 3\rDifference between observed and dark diversity CWM for (A) growth rate, (B) lateral extension, (C) maximum height, (D) seed weight, (E) dispersal, (F) seed production, and (G) specific leaf area in 18 naturally recovering smelter  _impacted forests and three reference forests in Sudbury, Ontario, Canada.
#Text=Bold indicates significant differences between observed and dark diversity species tested using non  _parametric Kruskal�Wallis test.
#Text=The PCA of environmental variables revealed six significant principal components.
#Text=The first two axes (Fig �4A) explained 49.41% of the total variance.

#Text=Axis 1 (28.85%) captured a gradient of smelter impact: positive values indicated sites with higher canopy cover located further from smelters, while negative values occurred for sites closer to smelters with higher contaminant concentrations (As, Cu, Pb, and Ni).

#Text=Axis 2 (20.56%) reflected soil health variation: negative values were associated with healthier soils (higher soil pH and greater base saturation, ammonium, and cation availability), while positive values indicated poorer soil health and low productivity (lower soil pH, higher Fe, higher extractable P, and greater CEC).

#Text=Figure 4\rPrincipal component analysis biplots of (A) selected environmental variables, (B) CWM of traits of observed species (green, continuous lines) and dark diversity species (black, dashed lines) in 18 naturally recovering smelter  _impacted forests and three reference forests in Sudbury, Ontario, Canada.
#Text=Point size is proportional to distance from the smelter (larger points are further from the smelters).
#Text=The PCA of CWM of traits of observed and dark species revealed five significant principal component axes.
#Text=The first two axes are presented in Figure�4B�and explain 54.41% of the total variance in the data.

#Text=Along axis 1 (37.08%), sites further from smelters (large data points on the negative end of the axis) had a higher prevalence of tall species, large seeded species, and species with high lateral extension.
#Text=Dark diversity species toward the end of this axis had large SLA values and high lateral extension.
#Text=Toward the positive end of the axis were sites closer to smelters (small data points), and the observed species had large SLA values and high seed production.
#Text=Dark diversity species at this end of the axis were tall with large seeds and high seed production.
#Text=Toward the positive end of axis 2 (17.33%) were located a few sites very close to smelters, where observed species were tall with rapid growth rates and high seed production.
#Text=At this end, dark diversity species had high dispersal.
#Text=Sites on the negative end of axis 2 were associated with large  _seeded observed species and rapid  _growing dark diversity species, which also coincided with sites further from smelters.

#Text=Among the species with the highest dark diversity probabilities, we found bird  _dispersed tree species (Picea mariana�and�Pinus strobus), fruit  _bearing shrubs (Ilex mucronata,�Amelanchier�sp., and�Dirca palustris), small fruit  _bearing evergreen shrubs (Gaultheria procumbens�and�G. hispidula), and small  _seeded species with specific substrate germination requirements (Cypripedium acaule,�Dryopteris marginalis, and�Lycopodium complanatum).
#Text=The first two axes of the trait space PCA of these species are presented within Figure�5�and explain 57.34% of the total variance in the data.

#Text=Figure 5\rPrincipal components analysis of the traits (red) for the 10% of species with the highest dark diversity probability in 18 naturally recovering smelter  _impacted forests and three reference forests in Sudbury, Ontario, Canada.
#Text=Photos were added manually to aid in visualization, with species names for each photo in blue.
#Text=All photos are covered by the Creative Commons Zero license (CC0) and were obtained from iNaturalist (2024).
#Text=Discussion.

#Text=Community Completeness Index as a Measure of Natural Recovery Success\rPlant community recovery following disturbance is typically evaluated by estimating the magnitude of community change and/or the recovery rate of plant communities in comparison with the attributes of a reference ecosystem (Wortley et al�2013; Gatica  _Saavedra et al�2017).
#Text=Here we suggest a complementary approach to traditional metrics that focuses on the functional identity of absent species, rather than the identity of frequently observed species.
#Text=We found that dark diversity and CCI were useful in providing complementary information regarding the state of recovery at disturbed sites.

#Text=Identifying species and functional syndromes that are recovering as well as those that have a delayed recovery is an essential component of measuring restoration success (Lewis et al�2017; Sluis�2020).

#Text=At the level of the plant community, CCI indicates whether desirable species are being gained or lost, and if sites are approaching a desirable target community (P�rtel et al�2013; Noreika et al�2020).
#Text=For example, we found that sites with low CCI were furthest from their target communities as they were missing many suitable species.
#Text=These sites may benefit from restoration interventions that facilitate the recovery of these species.

#Text=This approach is particularly useful when undisturbed reference sites are not available, as we can use the habitat  _specific species pool as a target ecosystem and evaluate which species are absent (Lewis et al�2017; Prach et al�2020).

#Text=Why Are Species Absent  Identifying Traits of Dark Diversity Species and Barriers to Species Recovery\rBy comparing the mean trait values of observed and dark diversity species, we identified traits associated with species ability to recover passively in smelter  _impacted forests.

#Text=Identifying traits linked to dark diversity can reveal obstacles to recovery and provide a more thorough understanding of the community assembly processes at play in the recovering plant community (Lewis et al�2017; Moeslund et al�2017).
#Text=In our study, species with high dark diversity probabilities were generally taller than observed species and/or had larger seed weights.

#Text=We did not anticipate this relationship with maximum height, as it has been associated with competitive vigor and the ability to quickly colonize disturbance prone habitats (Westoby et al�2002).

#Text=The low prevalence of seedlings of taller species in the naturally recovered understory was likely due to the initial colonization and subsequent dominance of quick growing pioneer species that can tolerate soil metal stress, combined with the poor recovery of taller, later successional conifer species.

#Text=Later successional conifer species such as�Pinus strobus,�Picea glauca, and�Abies balsamea�were extensively harvested within the region and are known to be sensitive to sulfur emissions (Linzon�1972; Freedman & Hutchinson�1980; Winterhalder�1995).
#Text=Many conifer species lack suitable seedbeds for germination in this region because of the erosion and metal contamination of the soils in the study area (Winterhalder�1995).
#Text=Furthermore, PCA of the CWM of traits indicated that the observed species followed two main functional continua of plant economics and size (D�az et al�2016; Bruelheide et al�2018).

#Text=Both functional continua coincided with distance from the smelter, with a higher prevalence of traits associated with fast resource acquisition (high SLA, rapid growth rate, and high seed production) and small size (low maximum height and small seed size) closer to smelters.

#Text=Species with these traits are well  _adapted to colonize and thrive in early post  _disturbance habitats where competition for belowground resources is low and light availability is high (Reich�2014; Hemrov� & M�nzbergov��2015).

#Text=In areas further from smelters, where the canopy has recovered and natural succession is more advanced, we observed larger species (taller and larger seeds) with more conservative,   slow    traits (low SLA values, slower growth rate, and lower seed production), associated with later successional species (Reich�2014; Hemrov� & M�nzbergov��2015).
#Text=Even though smelter emissions had declined over the 30 years prior to this study, later successional species were still not able to passively colonize highly impacted areas.
#Text=To recover some of these absent species, active restoration will be needed to improve establishment conditions or circumvent dispersal limitations (Braun�2007; Santala et al�2016).
#Text=We also found that observed species had smaller seed weights than dark diversity species, indicating that dispersal or establishment are likely barriers to recovery within some sites.

#Text=While smaller seeds have been associated with greater dispersal abilities, some research suggests that dispersal is predominantly influenced by plant height rather than seed mass (Thomson et al�2011; Tamme et al�2014).

#Text=Seed mass may thus exert a more substantial influence on dispersal through its effects on establishment success, namely through its positive relationship with resource availability and negative relationship with light availability (Vandelook et al�2018; DeMalach et al�2019).
#Text=Lack of canopy cover and poor soil quality in our study sites may favor the more rapid recovery of smaller seeded species in the Sudbury area.

#Text=Several studies in the region have identified poor dispersal, a lack of soil organic matter, and the presence of metal toxicity in soils as important factors limiting plant establishment, particularly in heavily impacted areas, which may explain why larger seeded species are lacking (Courtin�1994; Gunn et al�1995; Winterhalder�1995; Santala et al�2016).
#Text=We also found that several bird  _dispersed species had a high dark diversity probability (i.e.
#Text=�Amelanchier�sp.,�Dirca palustris,�Ilex mucronata,�P. strobus, and�Picea mariana).
#Text=The recovery of these long  _distance dispersed species may be hindered by a lack of suitable habitat patches and/or low movement between patches (Chazdon�2013; T�r�k & Helm�2017).
#Text=Even if species are able to disperse seed, contaminated seed beds likely limit their establishment (Winterhalder�1995).
#Text=We also found that many ferns and allies with small spores or seeds able to travel long distance, have a high dark diversity probability (i.e.
#Text=�Dryopteris marginalisand�Lycopodium clavatum, as well as the orchid�Cypripedium acaule).

#Text=These species have narrow establishment requirements related to temperature, light, moisture, and microtopography conditions, which limit their capacity for colonization following disturbance (Flinn�2007; Paul et al�2014).
#Text=Orchids such as�C. acaule�rely on highly specialized mycorrhizal and pollinator associations (Gijbels et al�2012).
#Text=Thus, enhancement of soil conditions will be required to improve the germination, establishment, and subsequent recovery of these species.

#Text=In areas where soil conditions have improved, species with high dark diversity probabilities and limited dispersal abilities could be considered for introductions (Mackenzie & Naeth�2010; Brunet et al�2011).
#Text=For example, slow  _growing species with low dispersal, such as�Gaultheria procumbens�and�G. hispidula, may require restoration interventions for their recovery (Santala et al�2016).

#Text=These species require suitable microhabitats, including the presence of coarse woody debris, heterogeneous microtopography, or low light conditions for their successful colonization (Aubin et al�2008; Griffiths & McGee�2018).

#Text=Using Trait  _Based Dark Diversity Metrics in Restoration Monitoring: Strengths and Limitations\rOur study showcases potential uses of trait  _based dark diversity approaches to inform restoration practices, including the prioritization of restoration sites or targeting interventions toward absent species.

#Text=While trait  _based approaches are well implemented in restoration ecology (Carlucci et al�2020; Aubin et al�2024), there are implications and potential drawbacks that remain to be addressed before dark diversity can be efficiently used for restoration:\rDefining the habitat species pool�is complex and must be critically assessed to ensure accurate results (T�r�k & Helm�2017).

#Text=The species pool should be defined based on a reference or target system realistic for the study area, including only sites that represent the habitat intended to be restored (i.e. target community).
#Text=For instance, in the context of Sudbury, we selected upland mesic to xeric sites of 17 stand types commonly found in the area as realistic target communities.

#Text=This may be an issue when there is low availability of vegetation plot data in the region, as the quality of dark diversity estimations depends on the quantity and quality of available data (Lewis et al�2017).
#Text=For some regions, large  _scale inventories are scarce.
#Text=In our area, the only large  _scale forest vegetation assessments dates to the 1980s.
#Text=The use of historical data may also be problematic, as these forests may no longer represent realistic reference targets due to global change.

#Text=Habitat degradation and rapid global change threaten communities, and restored ecosystems may be more likely to transition toward novel species mixtures, thus resulting in hybrid or novel ecosystems (Hobbs et al�2009).

#Text=The use of dark diversity is interesting in the sense that it can be used to circumvent these issues by using flexible, species pool  _based target systems, which rely on the species already present within the region that are expected to be able to disperse, establish, survive, and reproduce in the site (Zobel�2016; Lewis et al�2017).

#Text=The use of habitat  _specific species pools can therefore be used to tailor dark diversity estimations for specific target ecosystems or even novel ecosystems by identifying the species that are required to achieve a novel target ecosystem (Lewis et al�2017).

#Text=For example, practitioners in the Sudbury area are looking toward enrichment plantations to create rich, diverse hardwood forests, which have a limited historical distribution within the area,�but are projected to extend further north with climate change (Freedman & Hutchinson�1980; Prasad et al�2020).
#Text=By estimating dark diversity using hardwood stands as a target ecosystem, we can determine the species that are required to reach this target ecosystem.
#Text=Low dark diversity probabilities at the species level�remain difficult to ecologically interpret.
#Text=The total dark diversity probability of a species is calculated as the sum of probabilities for the species within all sites (Carmona & P�rtel�2020).
#Text=When calculated in this way, a species can have a low total dark diversity probability for two reasons: (1) the species is frequently observed (null dark diversity, e.g.
#Text=�Betula papyrifera�which had low dark diversity but was frequently observed within sites), or (2) the species is frequently absent from sites but would not be expected within sites (e.g.
#Text=�Athyrium filix  _femina�or�Equisetum sylvaticum, which have low occurrences in both the local and regional datasets).

#Text=At the community level, dark diversity is calculated as the sum of probabilities of all species absent from the site, and low or null species will simply be disregarded, facilitating more ecologically meaningful interpretations.

#Text=However, at the species level, it can be difficult to discriminate between species that are frequently absent and would be expected to be, and those that are frequently observed, as they both have low total dark diversity probabilities within the region.
#Text=This issue makes it difficult to interpret individual species dark diversity probabilities in relation to traits without a good understanding of common community types within the study region.

#Text=By analyzing the CWM values of traits, we believe we circumvented these issues, as absent species will not influence the mean values, while the more abundant observed or dark diversity species will have greater weight on the CWM values.

#Text=This may explain the lower variance of CWM for dark diversity species, since each species is assigned a dark diversity probability, and therefore a greater number of species contribute to the calculation of CWM, even if their contribution is low.

#Text=Due to these difficulties, simple descriptions of the traits of species with the highest dark diversity probabilities may be a more dependable method for evaluating traits related to dark diversity.
#Text=Further research is needed to refine probabilistic dark diversity methodologies for practical application.
